metadata.titleEn: Temperature and precipitation data at meteorological stations in five Central Asian countries (1980-2015)
metadata.description:
The data set covers 599 meteorological stations in five Central Asian countries, including the following elements: * daily maximum temperature, * daily minimum temperature, * observed temperature, * Precipitation (i.e. rain, melting snow), covering the following dates: 1980-1986; 1996-2005; 2010; 2014; 2015
The data comes from ghcn-d, a data set containing global land area daily observation data, which integrates climate records.
The data is a direct measurement of surface temperature, without interpolation or model assumptions, and contains many long-term site records. The disadvantage is uneven space coverage. Due to changes in observation time, site location, and the type of thermometer used, the records contain many heterogeneity.
For more information about this dataset, see https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/ghcnd-data-access
metadata.instructions:
The following information serves as a definition of each field in one line of data covering one station-day. Each field described below is separated by a comma ( , ) and follows the order
presented in this document.

ID = 11 character station identification code
YEAR/MONTH/DAY = 8 character date in YYYYMMDD format (e.g. 19860529 = May 29, 1986)
ELEMENT = 4 character indicator of element type 
DATA VALUE = 5 character data value for ELEMENT 
M-FLAG = 1 character Measurement Flag 
Q-FLAG = 1 character Quality Flag 
S-FLAG = 1 character Source Flag 
OBS-TIME = 4-character time of observation in hour-minute format (i.e. 0700 =7:00 am)

For more information on this data set, please visit the GHCN Daily Website http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/ghcn-daily/

background: The analysis of multidecadal climate trends and variability is commonly based on monthly and annual summaries of station-based weather data, and records of this time resolution have been widely available in digital form for decades (e.g., Jones et al. 1985, 1986; Vose et al. 1992). However, monthly means and averages are not sufficient for all climate applications. For example, the analysis of changes in the length of the growing season (Kunkel et al. 2004), changes in the frequency of heavy precipitation (Min et al. 2011), and changes in heat wave frequency and duration (Della Marta et al. 2007) all require data at least at the daily resolution. Unfortunately, daily data are comparatively less accessible than monthly values, in part because of impediments (e.g., mandates for cost recovery) in many countries for releasing daily climate data for widespread public use (Alexander et al. 2006). This relative paucity of daily data hampers climate change analysis and model comparison studies (Trenberth et al. 2007).
research objective: Here, a database is described whose aim is to address the need for daily climate data over global land areas.
methods: In addition, two checks have been manually performed to identify stations with grossly incorrect coordinates: 1) a comparison of each station’s elevation to the Global One-Kilometer Base Elevation (GLOBE) dataset (Globe Task Team et al. 1999) and 2) a comparison of the long-term monthly station averages of maximum temperature, minimum temperature, and total precipitation to an independently constructed gridded dataset of monthly values (Legates and Willmott 1990a,b). A semiautomatic method for identifying large jumps and other erratic behavior in time series of annual totals was also applied. Gross shifts in precipitation time series were identified by means of the standard normal homogeneity test (Alexandersson 1986) applied to station time series of annual precipitation totals computed from the daily data. A manual examination of station records where maximum and minimum temperatures failed the outlier and/or inconsistency checks at least 300 times revealed two problems. In the last record integrity check, U.S. temperature records for which the time of observation has been documented are tested for inconsistencies between the reported observation time and the reported temperatures.
dataset: The dataset, known as Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN)-Daily, was developed for a wide variety of potential applications, including climate analysis and monitoring studies that require data at a daily time resolution (e.g., assessments of the frequency of heavy rainfall, heat wave duration, etc.). The dataset contains records from over 80 000 stations in 180 countries and territories, and its processing system produces the official archive for U.S. daily data. Variables commonly include maximum and minimum temperature, total daily precipitation, snowfall, and snow depth; however, about two-thirds of the stations report precipitation only.

background: One of the most active areas of climatological research is the study of changes in the frequency and intensity of extreme events. In the past, limitations in data availability and computational resources have frequently restricted such studies to particular countries, regions, or individual locations. Thanks to technological advances as well as a greater willingness of countries to share their daily observations, it has become possible to assemble and regularly update a global dataset of historical daily meteorological observations. GHCN-Daily consists of more than 1,500,000,000 observations at over 40,000 land-based stations, some of which date back to the mid-1800s. With this diversity of data comes a large variety of measurement, recording, digitization, transmission, and processing problems. Consequently, procedures that can ensure high-quality historical and real-time daily data are critical.
research objective: This paper describes a comprehensive set of fully automated quality assurance (QA) procedures for observations of daily surface temperature, precipitation, snowfall, and snow depth. The QA procedures are being applied operationally to the Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN)-Daily dataset. The system consists of 19 carefully evaluated tests that detect duplicate data, climatological outliers, and various inconsistencies (internal, temporal, and spatial).
challenges: Although effective, the semiautomatic approach is impractical for datasets as large as GHCN-Daily, which must be reprocessed regularly to incorporate additional historical and real-time data. Therefore, the challenge is to design a QA system that, without manual intervention, is effective at detecting a variety of data errors and that has a low false-positive rate, or fraction of flagged values that are false positives. Unfortunately, the electronic data files do not include an indication of whether the reported value is due to snow, hail, or another form of frozen precipitation, often making it virtually impossible for either data users or QA procedures to distinguish reports of hail from the at least equally frequent, erroneous, warm-season nonzero values in the SNOW and SNWD fields.
methods: Manual review of random samples of the values flagged as errors is used to set the threshold for each procedure such that its false-positive rate, or fraction of valid values identified as errors, is minimized. In addition, the tests are arranged in a deliberate sequence in which the performance of the later checks is enhanced by the error detection capabilities of the earlier tests. The QA of daily surface observations is frequently performed in a semiautomatic fashion in which trained validators examine a subset of values flagged by the automatic procedures and override the system’s decision whenever they deem a flagged value to be valid. The GHCN-Daily QA system consists of procedures that test for all of the above-mentioned types of data errors. Many of these are replicates or extensions of checks employed by others, while others, such as the frequent-value and megaconsistency checks, utilize concepts that have received little or no attention in the peer-reviewed literature. Each individual check in the GHCN-Daily QA system is required to have a false-positive rate of no more than 20%. To ensure adherence to this requirement, each test is applied in a preliminary fashion to the entire GHCN-Daily dataset. Random samples of flagged values are then manually inspected for a range of plausible test thresholds, and the fraction of false positives in each sample is determined. The tests in the GHCN-Daily system can be grouped into five general categories that are executed in the following order: basic integrity checks, outlier tests, internal and temporal consistency checks, spatial consistency checks, and “megaconsistency” checks.
dataset: The QA procedures are being applied operationally to the Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN)-Daily dataset. GHCN-Daily consists of more than 1,500,000,000 observations at over 40,000 land-based stations, some of which date back to the mid-1800s. The primary meteorological elements represented include daily maximum and minimum temperature (TMAX and TMIN), 24-h precipitation (PRCP) and snowfall (SNOW) totals, and the snow depth at a certain time of day (SNWD).
findings: Based on an assessment of each individual check and a final evaluation for each element, the system identifies 3.6 million (0.24%) of the more than 1.5 billion maximum/minimum temperature, precipitation, snowfall, and snow depth values in GHCN-Daily as errors, has a false-positive rate of 1%22%, and is effective at detecting both the grossest errors as well as more subtle inconsistencies among elements.

background: The analysis of multidecadal climate trends and variability is commonly based on monthly and annual summaries of station-based weather data, and records of this time resolution have been widely available in digital form for decades. However, monthly means and averages are not sufficient for all climate applications. For example, the analysis of changes in the length of the growing season, changes in the frequency of heavy precipitation, and changes in heat wave frequency and duration all require data at least at the daily resolution. research objective: Here, a database is described whose aim is to address the need for daily climate data over global land areas.
challenges: However, there has been no formal mechanism or requirement to share daily data via the GTS and no central repository for daily climate reports from national surface networks. In practice, the transmission of daily climate summaries has been treated as optional even for the network of stations that report temperature, precipitation, surface pressure, etc., at fixed synoptic hours. Similarly, stations in the WMO’s Regional Basic Climate Network are only required to provide a monthly climate summary known as CLIMAT and likewise do not consistently transmit daily summaries within their synoptic messages.
methods: In addition, two checks have been manually performed to identify stations with grossly incorrect coordinates: 1) a comparison of each station’s elevation to the Global One-Kilometer Base Elevation (GLOBE) dataset (Globe Task Team et al. 1999) and 2) a comparison of the long-term monthly station averages of maximum temperature, minimum temperature, and total precipitation to an independently constructed gridded dataset of monthly values (Legates and Willmott 1990a,b). A semiautomatic method for identifying large jumps and other erratic behavior in time series of annual totals was also applied.
dataset: The dataset, known as Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN)-Daily, was developed for a wide variety of potential applications, including climate analysis and monitoring studies that require data at a daily time resolution. The dataset contains records from over 80,000 stations in 180 countries and territories, and its processing system produces the official archive for U.S. daily data. Variables commonly include maximum and minimum temperature, total daily precipitation, snowfall, and snow depth; however, about two-thirds of the stations report precipitation only. The international collection contains historical records for approximately 20,000 locations outside the United States (from over 100 different countries) and largely reflects the data collection efforts for GDCN. Well over 200 million values of maximum and minimum temperatures and total daily precipitation are included in this collection.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'spatial consistency checks' in meteorological data quality assurance?
Definition.Answer: In meteorological data quality assurance, 'spatial consistency checks' refer to procedures that compare data from a specific station with data from nearby stations to identify discrepancies that may indicate errors. These checks help ensure that the reported data are consistent with the spatial patterns expected based on the geographic and climatic context.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data accessibility and challenges between daily climate data and monthly climate summaries in global meteorological datasets?
Comparison.Answer: Daily climate data are less accessible due to impediments like cost recovery mandates and lack of a central repository, which hampers climate change analysis. Monthly summaries are more widely available but insufficient for applications requiring daily resolution. Challenges include the lack of formal mechanisms for sharing daily data and the optional transmission of daily summaries.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be inferred from the varying methods used to ensure data quality in global meteorological observations?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges inferred from the methods used to ensure data quality in global meteorological observations include designing a quality assurance system that effectively detects a variety of data errors without manual intervention, while maintaining a low false-positive rate. Additionally, there are complexities in distinguishing between different types of precipitation, such as snow and hail, which can complicate data accuracy and quality assurance processes.

Interpretation.Question: How might the observed inconsistencies in temperature and precipitation records influence the interpretation of climate trends over multiple decades?
Interpretation.Answer: Observed inconsistencies in temperature and precipitation records could significantly influence the interpretation of climate trends over multiple decades by introducing errors that may obscure true climate signals. These inconsistencies can arise from changes in observation times, station locations, or equipment, and thus require careful quality assurance and data homogenization methods to ensure accurate trend analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the potential limitations of using monthly and annual climate data for detailed climate applications, compared to daily data?
Interpretation.Answer: The potential limitations of using monthly and annual climate data for detailed climate applications, as inferred from the data, include a lack of resolution necessary for analyzing specific climate phenomena such as changes in the frequency of extreme weather events, the length of the growing season, and heat wave duration. Daily data provide a finer temporal resolution that is essential for these types of analyses, which are important for understanding detailed climate dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in acquiring daily climate data necessary for comprehensive climate change analysis?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Daily climate data are less accessible than monthly values due to impediments such as mandates for cost recovery in many countries, which hampers climate change analysis and model comparison studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do historical daily meteorological observations often face a variety of measurement, recording, and processing problems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The diversity of data from over 40,000 land-based stations, some dating back to the mid-1800s, results in a large variety of measurement, recording, digitization, transmission, and processing problems, requiring critical QA procedures to ensure data quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the spatial coverage inconsistencies in the meteorological data collected from different stations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Spatial coverage inconsistency arises from changes in observation time, station location, and types of thermometers used, leading to many inhomogeneities in the records.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a semiautomatic method for identifying large jumps and erratic behavior in meteorological data series?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a semiautomatic method for identifying large jumps and erratic behavior in meteorological data series allows for the detection of gross shifts in precipitation time series, enhancing the reliability of the data. However, it may become impractical for very large datasets which require regular reprocessing, necessitating a fully automated system for efficiency and accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the absence of a formal mechanism for sharing daily climate data via the Global Telecommunication System (GTS) affect the availability and quality of global climate datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The absence of a formal mechanism for sharing daily climate data via the GTS results in inconsistent transmission of daily summaries, leading to a lack of comprehensive daily climate reports from national surface networks. This affects the availability and quality of global climate datasets, hindering detailed climate change analysis and model comparison studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement automated quality assurance procedures for daily meteorological observations in large-scale datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Automated quality assurance procedures are crucial for detecting a variety of data errors efficiently and regularly, given the vast size of datasets like GHCN-Daily, which must be reprocessed to incorporate additional historical and real-time data while maintaining a low false-positive rate.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind creating a global database for daily climate data, especially in terms of addressing challenges in climate change analysis?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to address the lack of accessible daily data, which is essential for analyzing multidecadal climate trends and variability, and to overcome impediments such as mandates for cost recovery that limit the release of daily climate data for public use.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the quality and accuracy of meteorological data collected from global land-based stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the quality and accuracy of meteorological data from global land-based stations, a comprehensive set of fully automated quality assurance (QA) procedures is applied. These procedures involve 19 carefully evaluated tests that detect duplicate data, climatological outliers, and various inconsistencies (internal, temporal, and spatial). The tests are arranged in a sequence to enhance the performance of later checks by utilizing the error detection capabilities of earlier ones. The QA system aims to minimize the false-positive rate for flagged values, achieved through manual review of random samples and setting appropriate thresholds.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers address the challenge of spatial coverage unevenness in climatological datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can address the challenge of spatial coverage unevenness by employing checks on station coordinates and elevation using datasets like the Global One-Kilometer Base Elevation (GLOBE) dataset. Additionally, comparisons are made between long-term monthly station averages and independently constructed gridded datasets of monthly values to identify incorrect coordinate data and ensure consistency. Implementing a semiautomatic method for detecting large jumps and erratic behavior in time series can also help address this issue.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have facilitated the global collection and regular updating of daily meteorological observations?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advances, such as improved data sharing mechanisms and computational resources, along with a greater willingness of countries to share daily observations, have facilitated the collection and regular updating of a global dataset of historical daily meteorological observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might daily climate data be less accessible than monthly data in the context of global climate studies?
Expectation.Answer: Daily data are comparatively less accessible than monthly values due to impediments such as mandates for cost recovery in many countries, which limit the release of daily climate data for widespread public use. This scarcity of daily data hampers climate change analysis and model comparison studies.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when designing a quality assurance system for a large climate dataset, and how can they be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: Designing a QA system for large datasets involves challenges such as effectively detecting a variety of data errors without manual intervention and maintaining a low false-positive rate. One approach is to use a comprehensive set of fully automated QA procedures, which includes arranging tests in a deliberate sequence to enhance performance and setting thresholds based on manual reviews to minimize false positives.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be inconsistencies in daily climate data even with systematic quality checks?
Expectation.Answer: Inconsistencies may arise because electronic data files often lack indications of whether reported values are due to snow, hail, or other forms of frozen precipitation. This makes it difficult to distinguish between actual reports and erroneous nonzero values in the SNOW and SNWD fields, posing a challenge for both data users and QA procedures.

Judgmental.Question: How effectively do current data collection methods address the challenges of gathering daily climate data over global land areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Current data collection methods for daily climate data over global land areas face several challenges, including a lack of central repositories for daily reports and optional transmission of daily summaries in many cases. Although the Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN)-Daily dataset attempts to address these needs by collecting data from over 80,000 stations in 180 countries, the relative inaccessibility of daily data compared to monthly values still hampers comprehensive climate change analysis.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can the quality assurance procedures for daily meteorological observations be improved to enhance data reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: Quality assurance procedures for daily meteorological observations can be improved by developing more effective automated systems with low false-positive rates. The current GHCN-Daily QA system uses a set of 19 tests that detect various inconsistencies, but manual review and setting appropriate thresholds are critical to minimizing false positives. Enhancing these procedures could involve refining error detection algorithms and incorporating additional checks for distinguishing between different forms of precipitation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the procedures employed to ensure data quality and accuracy in large-scale climatology datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Quality assurance procedures applied to large-scale climatology datasets like GHCN-Daily include a comprehensive set of fully automated tests that detect duplicate data, climatological outliers, and inconsistencies. These procedures consist of 19 carefully evaluated tests that minimize the false-positive rate and ensure high-quality historical and real-time daily data by arranging tests in a deliberate sequence to enhance error detection capabilities.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why daily climate data are less accessible than monthly values despite their importance for certain climate applications.
Assertion.Answer: Daily climate data are less accessible than monthly values due to various impediments, such as mandates for cost recovery in many countries, which limit the release of daily climate data for public use. This lack of accessibility hampers climate change analysis and model comparison studies, despite the necessity of daily resolution data for analyzing changes in the growing season length, heavy precipitation frequency, and heat wave duration.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the techniques used to ensure data quality and accuracy in daily climate datasets across global land areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN)-Daily dataset applies a comprehensive set of fully automated quality assurance procedures to ensure data accuracy. These include 19 tests to detect duplicate data, climatological outliers, and inconsistencies, arranged in a sequence to enhance performance, with manual reviews of flagged values to set thresholds and minimize false positives.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential methodologies for expanding the spatial coverage of meteorological datasets while maintaining data integrity.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding the spatial coverage involves addressing the uneven spatial distribution of meteorological stations, which can be achieved by integrating independent datasets like GLOBE for station elevation comparisons and employing the standard normal homogeneity test for detecting shifts in precipitation time series, thereby ensuring data integrity across expanded areas.
